Detailed Description

template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
class Driver< TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms >

Author:
Simon Wicks <simonw@phys.columbia.edu> A generic driver for a Monte Carlo calculation At run time, different random number generator can be used: for example pseudorandoms such as standard drand48(); quasirandoms such as Sobol sequences (the latter can vastly increase the rate of convergence of Monte Carlo integration).
Template parameters: TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms TcalcEngine is an object that performs the calculation, with the interface .SetParameters( Parameters inParams ) .SetRandoms( boost::array<numOfRandoms> randomNumbers ) .SetCoord( long coord, double value ) .GetAnswer( std::vector answers ) Tstore is an object in which to keep the results, with the interface .SetParameters( Parameters inParams ) .AddPoint( long dim1, long dim2, std::vector<double> result ) .WriteToFile( std::string filename, bool appendToFile ) numOfRandoms is the number of random numbers to be used in the simulation

TODO: add the number of dimensions of the result as a template parameter, generalize the iteration over deterministic dimensions to be n-dimensional add this number of deterministic dimensions as a template parameter

TODO: add multithreading, so that multiple calculation engines can be run in parallel while adding into the same data store

int Driver< TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms >::Setup ( std::string  resume,
std::string  inputFile 
) [inline]

Setup routine - read in runtime parameters, set up all objects as necessary ="y" to resume from a previous run, ="n" to start a new one Filename of a) previous run file if resuming (including runtime parameters on the end), or b) runtime parameters file if not resuming

Run a single iteration of the monte carlo simulation.

References Driver< TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms >::calculator, Driver< TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms >::randomGenerator, and Driver< TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms >::storage.

00179 {
00180   // The guts of the Monte Carlo calculation
00181   // For one iteration, we fetch in a set of random numbers,
00182   // (these are supplied as a uniform distribution over [0,1)
00183   // then pass this to the calculation object,
00184   // (which will transform them to the required limits)
00185   // then iterate over all the points in the deterministic dimensions,
00186   // getting the calculation result for each point,
00187   // and passing this result to the data store.
00188   // TODO: generalize the iteration over deterministic dimensions to n-dimensions,
00189   // with n chosen as a template parameter to the driver object
00190 
00191   // First, get the array of random numbers
00192   // TODO: change the interface to the random number generator
00193   // to ask / get a fixed size array using boost::array
00194   // At the moment, the change from a boost::array to a std::vector (MyArray)
00195   // is cumbersome / a hack
00196   boost::array<double, numOfRandoms> randomNumbers;
00197   SwArrays::MyArray randomNumbersTmp( numOfRandoms );
00198   randomGenerator->GetUniforms( randomNumbersTmp );
00199   for ( std::size_t i=0; i<numOfRandoms; ++i )
00200     randomNumbers[i] = randomNumbersTmp[i];
00201 
00202   // Pass the random numbers to the calculator object
00203   calculator.SetRandoms( randomNumbers );
00204 
00205   // Now iterate over the deterministic dimensions,
00206   // setting the new coordinate for each point in each dimension,
00207   // getting the answer and adding it to the data store
00208   // TODO: improve, to have arbitrary number of dimensions
00209   std::vector<double> tmp(1);
00210   for (long dim1=0; dim1<storage.GetLengthDim1(); ++dim1)
00211   {
00212     calculator.SetCoord( 1, storage.GetCoordDim1( dim1 ) );
00213 
00214     for (long dim2=0; dim2<storage.GetLengthDim2(); ++dim2)
00215     {
00216       calculator.SetCoord( 2, storage.GetCoordDim2( dim2 ) );
00217       calculator.GetAnswer( tmp );
00218       storage.AddPoint( dim1, dim2, tmp );
00219     }
00220   }
00221 }
